metadata.title: Transcranial Focused Ultrasound Neuromodulation of Voluntary Movement-related Cortical Activity in Humans

abstract.text: Transcranial focused ultrasound (tFUS) is an emerging non-invasive brain 2 stimulation tool for safely and reversibly modulating brain circuits. The 3 effectiveness of tFUS on human brain has been demonstrated, but how tFUS 4 influences the human voluntary motor processing in the brain remains 5 unclear. We apply low-intensity tFUS to modulate the movement-related 6 cortical potential (MRCP) originating from human subjects practicing a 7 voluntary foot tapping task. 64-channel electroencephalograph (EEG) is 8 recorded concurrently and further used to reconstruct the brain source 9 activity specifically at the primary leg motor cortical area using the 10 electrophysiological source imaging (ESI). The ESI illustrates the ultrasound 11 modulated MRCP source dynamics with high spatiotemporal resolutions.

The MRCP source is imaged and its source profile is further evaluated for 13 assessing the tFUS neuromodulatory effects on the voluntary MRCP. 14 Moreover, the effect of ultrasound pulse repetition frequency (UPRF) is 15 further assessed in modulating the MRCP. ESI results show that tFUS 16 significantly increases the MRCP source profile amplitude (MSPA) 17 comparing to a sham ultrasound condition, and further, a high UPRF 18 enhances the MSPA more than a low UPRF. This work provides the first 19 evidence of tFUS enhancing the human voluntary movement-related cortical 20 activity through excitatory modulation.

body_text.text: As an emerging non-invasive neuromodulation tool, the low-intensity 23 transcranial focused ultrasound (tFUS) delivers highly controllable 24 mechanical energy from transducers, penetrating the skull with relatively low 25 tissue attenuation and modulates the targeted brain circuits with high spatial 26 selectivity. tFUS is featured with a vast parametric space, and by tuning its 27 parameters, the ultrasound wave can be steered and be used to produce 28 excitatory or inhibitory neural effects. Such neuromodulatory effects of tFUS 29 for effective brain stimulation have been evidenced on a wide range of animal 30 models (Dallapiazza et al., 2018; Daniels et al., 2018; Folloni et al., 2019b;  31 Lee et al., 2016c; Mohammadjavadi et al., 2019; Tufail et al., 2011; Verhagen 32 et al., 2019; Yang et al., 2018; Yoon et al., 2019; Yu et al., 2016) and, recently, 33 demonstrated in humans (Lee et al., 2016a; Lee et al., 2015; Lee et al., 34 2016b; Lee et al., 2017; Legon et al., 2018a; Legon et al., 2018b; Legon et 35 al., 2014) . For instances, the low-intensity diagnostic ultrasound energy has 36 been shown to suppress the pain, improve the subjects' mood and global 37 affect (Hameroff et al., 2013) . A recent study on using ultrasonic thalamic 38 stimulation assisted a patient to recover consciousness after severe brain 39 injury (Monti et al., 2016) . 40 Among accumulating experimental demonstrations on healthy humans, a 41 pioneer study using low-frequency and low-intensity tFUS was able to 42 achieve robust neuromodulation effects at the primary somatosensory cortex 43 (S1), evidenced through the ultrasound-modulated sensory-evoked brain 44 activity recorded at electroencephalogram (EEG) sensors and the 45 enhancement of sensory discrimination abilities (Legon et al., 2014) . Another 46 pilot study on tFUS modulating the S1 circuits reported direct evoked limb 47 sensations and the ultrasound stimulation event-related potentials (ERPs) 48 specifically at C3 and P3 EEG electrodes (Lee et al., 2015) . Later, the 49 acoustic stimulation was ipsilaterally targeted at S1 and S2 (i.e. the 50 secondary somatosensory cortex) simultaneously by multiple transducers.

Extensive tactile sensations were elicited and reported by the human 52 subjects (Lee et al., 2016a) . 53 The visual cortex is also a well-studied brain target for tFUS research. On 54 human, researchers administered sonication to the primary visual cortex 55 (V1). From the concurrent blood-oxygenation-level-dependent (BOLD) 56 functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI), researchers observed 57 ultrasound-elicited brain activations at the targeted V1 as well as the related 58 visual and cognitive brain network. Sonication-mediated ERPs and 59 phosphene perception were also reported (Lee et al., 2016b) . Very recently, 60 the ultrasound-induced illusory visual percepts were further investigated by 61 applying repeated transcranial diagnostic ultrasound at visual cortical region 62 identified by transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) eliciting phosphene 63 (Schimek et al., 2020) .

The motor cortex has been one of the popular sonication targets on animal 65 models for eliciting direct brain activation by tFUS, demonstrated by more 66 direct motor response readout (Kim et al., 2014; King et al., 2013; Mehic et 67 al., 2014; Tufail et al., 2010; Ye et al., 2016; Yuan et al., 2020) and/or 68 measurements from the corresponding muscle activities using 69 electromyogram (EMG) (King et al., 2013; King et al., 2014; Qiu et al., 2017; 70 Yoon et al., 2019) . In spite of this, the demonstrations of tFUS modulation on 71 human motor cortex are somehow limited. One of the recent efforts was to 72 employ a 7-Tesla BOLD fMRI for observation of tFUS modulation in the 73 targeted finger representation areas in terms of neurovascular signal change 74 while the subjects performed a simultaneous cued finger tapping task. The 75 activation volume of the thumb motor representation area was significantly 76 increased by the tFUS neuromodulation (Ai et al., 2018) . Another effort was 77 to further test how the ultrasound effects the motor cortical excitability and 78 behavior output by developing a novel hybrid brain stimulation device for 79 concurrent transcranial ultrasound and magnetic stimulation (Legon et al., 80 2018b). The tFUS neural inhibitory effects were inspected and quantified 81 through the amplitude reduction of single-pulse motor-evoked potentials and 82 the attenuation of intracortical facilitation. Interestingly, the tFUS significantly 83 shortened the reaction time on a stimulus response task (Legon et al., 84 2018b).

However, our current understanding on how tFUS can influence the human 86 voluntary motor processing in the brain is still lacking. In this study, we test 87 the ultrasound neuromodulatory effects on movement-related cortical 88 potential (MRCP) which occurs during the preparation for and execution of 89 movement with clinical significance on rehabilitation in patients (Niazi et al., 90 2012; Shakeel et al., 2015; Spring et al., 2016; Xu et al., 2014) , scientific 91 research on studying motor skill learning (Wright et al., 2011) , and enhancing 92 the brain-computer interface (BCI) (Dremstrup et al., 2013; Liu et al., 2020) .

Beyond the EEG delineation at the sensor level, in this study, we employ 94 scalp EEG based electrophysiological source imaging (ESI) (He and Ding, 95 2013; He et al., 2018; Yu et al., 2016) Furthermore, by virtue of computer modeling and simulations (Plaksin et al., 100 2016), the ultrasound pulse repetition frequency (UPRF) has been deemed 101 as one of the critical ultrasound parameters to achieve excitatory/inhibitory 102 neural effects. In a recent study, the acoustic radiation force produced by the 103 UPRF has been inferred as the most crucial source of behavioral responses 104 (Kubanek et al., 2018) . Most recently, the UPRF was also found as a critical 105 parameter in balancing the excitatory/inhibitory neuronal activities (Yu et al., 106 2019). In this study, we further assess the role of UPRF in modulating the 107 human MRCP. were later used to identfy the brain target through FreeSurfer cortical 121 reconstruction (Dale et al., 1999; Desikan et al., 2006) for guidance of the 122 low-intensity focused ultrasound focus.

During the tFUS-EEG session, the subject was seated inside a sound and 124 electromagnetic shielding room (IAC Acoustics, USA) and was instructed to impedance of all electrodes was kept below 10 kΩ during the EEG capping.

Positions of electrodes were digitized over each subjects' scalp using an 136 optical-based EEG PinPiont system (Localite GmbH, Germany). The 137 ultrasound transducer was held and mounted on top of the EEG cap using a 138 3D-printed helmet. An optical-based brain navigation system (Localite GmbH, 139 Germany) was utilized with the input of the structural MRI data and an optical Figure 1 ). This trigger signal was further stretched to 179 5 msec long by TriggerBox (Brain Products GmbH, Germany) for 180 synchronization with EEG recordings. Once triggered, the first function 181 generator was used to create the UPRF and determine the number of pulses.

The second function generator was triggered by the output of the first one in 183 burst mode and generated ultrasound fundamental frequency (UFF) of the 184 sinusoidal waveforms and determined the number of cycles per pulse (CPP).

As illustrated in Figure 2A , this study used a UFF of 0.5 MHz, CPP number 186 of 100. Each sonication lasted for 500 msec with two levels of UPRF, i.e. 300 187 and 3000 Hz practiced in two sessions (denoted as "UPRF 300Hz" and 188 "UPRF 3000Hz", respectively). The ultrasound spatial peak pressure applied 189 to the scalp was measured as 809.2 kPa (shown in Figure 2B -C, spatial- The EEG was sampled at 5 kHz and filtered using a bandpass filter with the 220 lower cut-off frequency at 1 Hz and the higher cut-off frequency at 45 Hz.

The pre-stimulus period was set as 400 msec before the trigger signal, and Figure 3A , D, G, Figure 4A and Figure 6 ). For EEG-231 based source modeling and imaging, the boundary element method (BEM) 232 (Hämäläinen and Sarvas, 1989; He et al., 1987) head model for each human 233 subject was established using OpenMEEG (Gramfort et al., 2010) , which 234 consisted of three layers, i.e. scalp, skull and brain with relative conductivities 235 of 1, 0.0125 and 1, respectively. The minimum norm imaging (MNI) was used 236 to solve the inverse problem, thus reconstructing the cortical source activity.

The source activity was imaged using the MNI for the duration of sonication. second null hypothesis is that the UPRF change will have no effect on the 253 MRCP source amplitude. The Kruskal-Wallis rank sum test was performed 254 to examine this hypothesis. Next, paired Wilcoxon test was further employed 255 to assess whether the increased UPRF will lead to a stronger 256 neuromodulation effect. For both statistical tests above, we performed

The multi-channel EEG butterfly plots in Figures The panels of (C), (F) and (I) show more detailed views of the brain activities specifically at the primary 296 motor cortex (M1) in responses to the three ultrasound sessions, respectively. The ESI illustrated 297 reconstructed current source densities. The green patches in these ESI panels represent the seed 298 areas for further extracting the MRCP source profiles. Different color scale bars are used to allow 299 better presentation of the localized motor source at the cortical brain. L: left, R: right, A: anterior, P: 300 posterior. 301

The green patches overlaid on top of the ESI results in Figures 3C, F and I 302 were used to indicate the seed area of the cortical region of interest in our 303 study, i.e. primary leg motor area in left brain hemisphere. We extracted the 304 MRCP source activity from the identified area of 3.4 cm 2 confined in the 305 reconstructed source area. The resulted MRCP source profiles were 306 generated for subsequent analyses. Figure 4A presents the profiles for 307 comparisons directly among the three ultrasound conditions. In the source 308 domain, typical MRCP features were reconstructed and indicated with 309 horizontal arrows. The readiness potential (RP), also known as 310 Bereitschaftspotential, priors at the onset of movement (from -400 to -24 311 msec in Sham US and UPRF 300Hz; from from -400 to -20 msec in UPRF 312 3000Hz) and is involved in the movement preparation (Dremstrup et al., 313 2013) . According to the definition, it is more accurate to denote this MRCP 314 component as "late RP" given its neighboring timing to the movement onset.

Immediately following this late RP, the motor potential (MP) reflecting the 316 movement execution was reconstructed within a much short time period of 317 36-38 msec (from -24 to 12 msec in Sham US; from -24 to 14 msec in UPRF 318 300Hz; from -20 to 18 msec in UPRF 3000 Hz). Lastly, the MRCP source 319 profile reconstructed the third component, movement-monitoring potential 320 (MMP, from 12 to 178 msec in Sham US; from 14 to 362 msec in UPRF 321 300Hz; from 18 to 378 msec in UPRF 3000Hz), which controlled the 322 movement performance (Shakeel et al., 2015) . Based on the timing of with 25% and 75% quantiles (lower and upper hinges). Statistics by one-tail non-parametric paired 352
Wilcoxon rank sum test for examining the effect UPRF increase. *p < 0.05. 353
To further interpret the effect of UPRF in modulating the MRCP, a non-354 parametric analysis of variance (ANOVA) was performed using Kruskal-

Wallis rank sum test ( Figure 5A ). For this test, the Sham US condition can 356 be considered as a type of tFUS condition with UPRF of 0 Hz. As a result, 357 we found that the UPRF did play a significant role (Kruskal-Wallis chi-358 squared = 7.24, p < 0.05) in changing the MSPA of the human subjects.

However, the variance of observations in the condition of UPRF 3000Hz is 360 observed to be larger than the other two conditions. To further probe into a 361 more specific effect of the UPRF, the non-parametric paired Wilcoxon test 362 was further used ( Figure 5B ). Significantly higher MSPAs (V-statistic = 21, p 363 < 0.05) were observed by dosing the higher UPRF, i.e. 3000 Hz.

The MRCP magnitude was correlated with the elbow-flexion movement 365 property, such as the force and its speed (Siemionow et al., 2000) . To rule Figure 4A ) measurements, needs to be further investigated. As illustrated in 410 Figure 4A , the MRCP was initiated during the movement planning phase, i.e. 411 the RP, prior to the actual physical movement. In fact, the RP is raised as 412 early as 1.5 sec before the onset of movement (Shakeel et al., 2015) , which 413 may be useful to provide much earlier trigger signal for tFUS 414 neuromodulation, thus assisting the movement planning and preparation.

Since the MRCP can also be evoked by motor imagination (Shakeel et al., Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) (Gu et al., 2009) , it would be valuable 424 to have a non-invasive neuroimaging tool, such as ESI, to map and quantify 425 the MRCP source at specific brain circuits with high spatiotemporal 426 resolution, thus informing the non-invasive neuromodulation for guidance 427 and feedback (Yu et al., 2020) . Electrophysiological source imaging (ESI) 428 has been pursued to localize and image brain electrical sources from 429 noninvasive scalp recorded EEG/MEG, and demonstrated to provide greatly 430 enhanced spatial resolution than the raw EEG/MEG in many applications 431 (He & Ding, 2013; He et al, 2018; Sohrabour et al, 2020) . The EEG-based 432 ESI (He and Ding, 2013; He et al., 2018) has demonstrated its unique and 433 significant role for effectively identifying epileptogenic brain sources 434 (Sohrabpour et al., 2020) and enhancing the subjects' BCI performances 435 (Edelman et al., 2019) . Although fMRI has been harnessed to monitor and 436 assess the neuromodulatory effects of tFUS on animals models (Folloni et 437 al., 2019a; Verhagen et al., 2019; Yang et al., 2018; Yoo et al., 2011) and on 438 humans (Lee et al., 2016b) , the method does not directly measure the neural 439 activities and the strong static magnetic field may confoundingly alter the 440 cortical excitability (Nakagawa and Nakazawa, 2018; Oliviero et al., 2011) .

In addition, besides the substantial concerns of ultrasound device 442 compatibility with the magnetic field, the fMRI imaging pulse sequences may 443 inevitably induce ancillary brain activations, e.g. auditory responses. Hence, 444 a natural setting for monitoring the tFUS modulating human brain with high 445 spatiotemporal resolutions, like the ESI is desirable.

Low intensity tFUS neuromodulation is deemed as generally safe without 447 inducing serious adverse effects on humans upon careful control of the 448 ultrasound intensities (ISPPA: 11.56-17.12 W/cm 2 ) (Legon et al., 2020) .

Although our study administered less ultrasound intensities than those 450 applied in (Legon et al., 2020) and even much less than the FDA's guideline 451 (ISPPA ≤ 190 W/cm 2 ) (FDA, 2008), we were also cautious about the tFUS 452 safety on the subjects during the experiment sessions. We surveyed the 453 subjects with a brief questionnaire for report of symptoms, such as headache, 454 neck pain, dental pain, nausea, dizziness, anxiety, abnormal muscle Figure 5A ).

Due to the time limit in our experiment protocol, we were unable to test 463 extensive UPRF conditions. However, as the UPRF is highly correlated with 464 the ultrasound spatial-peak temporal-average intensity (ISPTA), by increasing 465 this frequency, the total acoustic energy deposited onto the targeted brain 466 area is correspondingly increased. It is reasonable to infer that the increased 467 ultrasound energy in a high UPRF condition leads to increased excitatory 468 effects at the human primary motor cortex. Future research efforts will adjust 469 UPP for different UPRF levels to maintain the total ultrasound energy as a 470 constant during the fixed sonication period to tease out whether UPRF 471 frequency encoding plays a role in the modulation effects.

Inevitably, we observed inter-subject differences in response to the tFUS 473 neuromodulation (shown in Figure 4B -C and Figure 5B ). Such differences 474 may be attributed to many factors. One of the crucial factors is the inter- (Mueller et al., 2017; Webb et al., 2018) .

FIGREF0.text: healthy human subjects were recruited in this experiment (10 males, 111 5 females, mean age of participants: 33.39±14.02 years). Each subject 112 attended on-site interview for safety screening and provided written informed 113 consent before participating the experiment. The study was reviewed and 114 approved by the Institutional Review Board at Carnegie Mellon University. 115 Experimental Setup 116 Prior to the tFUS-EEG session, each participant received a 3-Tesla 117 magnetization-prepared rapid gradient-echo (MP-RAGE) T1-weighted 118 structural magnetic resonance imaging (MRI, Siemens Verio) in order to 119 establish high-resolution individual brain anatomical models. The models 120

FIGREF1.text: 125 wear foam earplugs (3M, USA) during experimental sessions. A 24-inch LCD 126 monitor with a viewing distance of 50 cm was used to instruct each subject 127 to start or stop voluntary foot pedaling (illustrated in Figure 1). During the 128 task, an accelerometer (ADXL335, Adafruit Industries LLC, USA) mounted 129 on a foot pedal (Foot Control 704NS-GR, Elna Machine Parts, USA) detected 130 and transmitted the fast motion of foot pressing to ExG AUX Box (Brain 131 Products GmbH, Germany). Concurrent 64-channel EEG data were 132 acquired using BrainAmp (Brain Products GmbH, Germany), with electrode 133 positions FCz and AFz chosen as reference and ground. The electrical 134

FIGREF2.text: 140 marker attached over the forehead to track and guide the position and 141 orientation of the ultrasound transducer in real time. Surface adhesive 142 electrodes (Medi-trace 530 series, Covidien, USA) were applied onto the 143 skin of calf and were connected to ExG AUX Box (Brain Products GmbH, 144 Germany) for monitoring muscle activities at the lower leg for validating each experimental design is shown in Figure 1. The motion task was 148 repeated in three sessions with respective ultrasound setup in a random 149 order (see details in Ultrasound Setup). The subjects were instructed to 150 initiate pressing the foot pedal using their right leg roughly every 3-5 seconds 151 on their own discretion after the screen turned to green color. About 120 trials 152 of right foot pedaling were conducted and recorded. The subjects were 153 instructed to keep the upper body still and eyes open. The subjects stopped 154 foot motion once the screen turned to red. 155 Diagram of the overall experimental setup. The voluntary right foot pedaling generates the 157 motion signal, and only the onset of this motion signal (from a fast-response, high-precision 158 comparator) is detected as the trigger signal for transmitting transcranial focused ultrasound (tFUS) 159 onto the primary leg motor area. The concurrent 64-channel electroencephalogram (EEG) is recorded 160 for electrophysiological source imaging (ESI). The reconstructed source activity at the leg motor 161 cortical area is further extracted and the movement-related cortical potential (MRCP) source profiles 162 are thus derived for further assessing the tFUS neuromodulatory effects. The electromyogram (EMG) 163 is recorded simultaneously for monitoring and validating successful voluntary foot pedaling trials. The 164 subject is instructed to wear earplugs throughout each testing session. 165 Ultrasound Setup 166 A single-element focused ultrasound transducer with an acoustic aperture 167 diameter of 25.4 mm and a nominal focal distance of 38 mm (AT31529, 168 Blatek Industries, Inc., USA) was used in this study. A 3D-printed collimator 169 (made in VeroClear resin) was attached to the transducer in order to match 170 the focal length of the transducer with the estimated physical distance from 171 the acoustic aperture to the targeted motor cortex. The ultrasound signal was 172 generated by two function generators (33220A, Keysight Technologies, Inc., USA) and amplified by a radiofrequency (RF) power amplifier (2100L, 174 Electronics & Innovation, Ltd., USA), driving the ultrasound transducer. The 175 first function generator was triggered by an output signal from a home-made 176 circuit based on a fast and precise voltage comparator (AD790, Analog 177 Devices Inc., USA), which was monitoring the output from the accelerometer 178 in real time (shown in

FIGREF3.text: 190 peak pulse-average intensity ISPPA: 5.90 W/cm 2 ), with an estimated 191 ultrasound pressure of 288.3 kPa (Figure 2D, ISPPA: 1.17 W/cm 2 ) arriving at 192 the targeted cortical brain with an acoustic insertion loss of -8.96 dB. This 193 pressure estimation was based on a 3-dimensional ex-vivo transcranial 194 ultrasound scanning using a needle hydrophone (HNR-0500, Onda Corp. 195 USA) placed in a full real human skull sample (OK-14472, Skulls Unlimited 196International, Inc., USA) and driven by a 3-axis precision motion system 197 (BiSlide system, Velmex Inc., USA). FromFigure 2B, it can be seen that the 198 -3dB contour of the focus is about 3 mm, and this focal size makes the 199 administered tFUS eligible to spatially targeting at the leg motor cortical area.200 A sham tFUS session was also introduced for rigorous comparisons. In this 201 sham condition (denoted as "Sham US"), the effective acoustic aperture was 202 physically detached from subject's scalp for 4-6 centimeters while the 203 transducer was still transmitting ultrasound at the UPRF of 3000 Hz. 204 Temporal and spatial profiles of the ultrasound for modulating the MRCP. (A) The temporal 206 waveforms of the pulsed tFUS triggered by the foot pedaling motion. (B-C) The lateral and axial views 207 of the ultrasound focus and beam in free water measured with a 3D pressure scanning system. (D) 208 The axial view of the transcranial ultrasound beam within a full real human skull sample. The smaller 209 Z number along the axial view represents the shorter distance from the transducer's acoustic exit 210 plane. 211 Electrophysiological Signal Processing 212The lower leg EMG, sampled at 5 kHz, was used to assess the quality of 213 each foot pedaling trial. During the offline data processing, we scrutinized 214 the signals from the EMG and the accelerometer demonstrated inFigure 1,215    and removed the trials reported from the accelerometer while the EMG 216 signals of those trials were not validated as a normal foot pressing activity.217This step was to exclude unintentional foot movement, like foot slipping or 218 uncompleted foot pedaling.

FIGREF5.text: 222 the period of 600 msec after the onset of the trigger signal was deemed as 223 post-stimulus period in EEG individual epoch. Independent component 224 analysis (ICA) (Makeig et al., 2002) and/or signal-space projection (SSP) 225 (Uusitalo and Ilmoniemi, 1997) were used to identify and clean artifacts, 226 mainly the strong eye blinking during the voluntary movement. The MRCPs 227 in the time domain were normalized against the first 100 msec during the 228 pre-stimulus period. The 1-second EEG epochs were then averaged across 229 the trials for each experimental condition by aligning the detected trigger 230 signal (i.e. Time 0 in

FIGREF6.text: , we took a source patch with an area of 3.2 -3.5 cm 2 from the 239 primary leg motor area of reconstructed MRCP source activity. The 240 measurement of MRCP source was the averaged activity across the patch.241The temporal dynamics of the MRCP measurements were depicted as a time242 profile within the 1-sec epoch period. The peak-to-peak amplitude of MRCP 243 source profile was then used for comparisons and statistical analyses. The 244 EEG signal processing was performed with Brainstorm toolbox (Tadel et al., 245 2011) in MATLAB R2018a (Mathworks, Inc., USA). 246 Statistical Analyses 247 Our statistical analyses focused on the tFUS modulation of the amplitude of 248 MRCP source profiles. The first null hypothesis to be tested is that the MRCP 249 source profile has no greater amplitude in the tFUS conditions than that in 250 the sham condition. For testing this hypothesis, we performed one-tail non-251 parametric paired Wilcoxon rank sum test to examine the tFUS effects. The252

FIGREF7.text: test for examining data normality. All the above statistical tests258 were conducted in R V3.2.1. In addition, due to the correlation between the 259 MRCP amplitude and movement strength, we investigated whether there 260 were significant differences regarding the foot pedaling strength across 261 different sessions for each subject, we did non-parametric permutation-262 based tests on the motion and EMG signals for ruling out such a possible 263 confound. These additional statistical analyses were performed with 264Brainstorm toolbox(Tadel et al., 2011).

FIGREF9.text: in terms of sensor-level MRCP amplitude due to the 268 presence of tFUS at the left primary leg motor area. Such EEG signal 269 amplitude increases were specifically detected at electrodes C1, FC1, Cz, 270 CPz and CP1, located close to the targeted brain area. In the Sham US 271 condition only with right foot pedaling, the EEG voltage topography map 272 reflected a mild activation at 17 msec majorly at the left brain hemisphere 273 (Figure 3B). 274 By applying the EEG-based source imaging, we further localized the MRCP 275 source activity at the precentral gyrus of left hemisphere, i.e. primary motor 276 area. The reconstructed MRCP source covered a region with an approximate 277 area of 4 cm 2 and exhibited a current source density (CSD) amplitude of 0.27 278 nA·m. This MRCP-related CSD amplitude was increased to 0.8 nA·m after 279 the tFUS (UPRF 300Hz) has been directed to the primary leg motor area 280 (Figure 3F). By increasing the UPRF to 3000 Hz while maintaining the 281 sonication duration, the MRCP was further enhanced at both the sensor level 282 (Figure 3G-H) and the source level (Figure 3I) even though the subjects 283 performed consistent foot pedaling motion (measured with motion signal 284 monitored by the accelerometer presented in Figure 6). With the modulation 285 of increased UPRF, the MRCP source amplitude was further increased to 2 286 nA·m. Besides the change of MRCP amplitudes, the emerging timing of 287 negative peak was also postponed from 2 msec in Sham US to 17 msec in 288 UPRF 300Hz condition, and further to 21 msec in the condition of UPRF 289 3000Hz. 290 Figure 3. The 3D EEG voltage topography maps (top view) show a whole-294 brain comparison between the three ultrasound conditions using the same color scale (B, E and H).

FIGREF13.text: 366 out the confounding factor of induvial subject difference in foot pedaling 367 motion, e.g. the strength and the speed of the leg/foot motion, we compared 368 each individuals' foot pedaling from the motion signals across all trials as 369 well as the three ultrasound sessions. An example of such comparison is 370 shown in Figure 6. Beyond visual inspection of Figure 6, we further 371 investigated whether the statistical differences among the motions in 372 different ultrasound sessions existed or not by using non-parametric 373 permutation-based statistical tests (5000 randomizations, two-tailed 374 Student's t-statistic, Bonferroni correction for the multiple comparisons) for 375 all the 1-second trials. No significant difference (p > 0.9) was found among 376 different sessions. Similarly, we tested the EMG signal profiles of all valid 377 trials, and still no significant difference was found among those three 378 sessions. With such evidence, one can attribute the observed effect on the 379 MRCPs (Figures 3-5) to the administered tFUS.

FIGREF14.text: The comparisons of foot pedaling motion signals across all the trials in each ultrasound 382 session, i.e. Sham US (A), UPRF 300Hz (B) and UPRF 3000 Hz (C). Arbitrary units (A.U.) are used 383 for describing the motion signals.3844. Discussions385In the present study, we introduced the MRCP induced by the real foot 386 pedaling movement as a metric to evaluate the tFUS neuromodulation effect387 on the human motor cortex. The results demonstrated that tFUS is able to 388 modulate the MRCP in an excitatory way, i.e. increasing the amplitude of 389 MRCP both at the EEG sensor level and at the source domain. One possible 390 mechanism to explain such an enhancement by the tFUS is that the focused 391 acoustic energy may increase excitability of the targeted brain circuit (Gibson 392 et al., 2018; Wang et al., 2019) for a short period. To pursue a high specificity 393 of MRCP readout, we extracted MRCP source activity from individual 394 anatomical brain model, specifically from the primary leg motor area by EEG 395 source imaging. Thus, we are able to reject most of artifacts presented in the 396 electrophysiological recordings with concurrent movement tasks, e.g. 397 unrelated body movements, eye blinks, and event-related sound. 398 Furthermore, we also found that the UPRF of tFUS stimulation plays a 399 positive role in modulation of the MRCP. The excitatory neuromodulation is 400 evidenced in the human primary motor cortex by increasing the UPRF, which 401 is in line with the prediction from computer simulations (Plaksin et al., 2016) 402 and our experimental observations from intracranial recordings at neuronal 403 level in animal models (Yu et al., 2019). 404 In our experimental paradigm, the tFUS transmission was triggered by the 405 onset of motion signal reflected in the MP phase. Therefore, the 500-msec 406 tFUS was majorly modulating the MMP component of a typical MRCP 407 complex. However, the delayed MMP due to the increased UPRF, i.e. the 408 postponed negative peaks in both sensor (Figures 3A, D and G) and source 409 (

FIGREF15.text: 416 2015), the demonstrated neuromodulation by tFUS would lead to more 417 applications in motor rehabilitation/prosthesis scenarios, in which tFUS can 418 be triggered by the early-phase MRCP source activity (i.e. early RP source) 419 of imagining a movement. 420 Given the importance of the MRCP in the scientific investigations on healthy 421 human subjects (Dremstrup et al., 2013) and clinical evaluations on patients 422 diagnosed with functional motor disorders, such as Parkinson's disease and 423

FIGREF17.text: 475 subject variation in skull morphology and composition. No linear relationship 476 was found either between the skull thickness and the transcranial maximal 477 acoustic pressure or between the skull thickness and the ultrasound full-478 width at half magnitude volume behind the skull (Mueller et al., 2017). To 479 address this issue, tFUS dose and target planning before the 480 neuromodulation experiment would be required and should be individualized; 481 such a planning may rely on a priori computer simulations for predicting 482 acoustic fields within individual skull cavity based on respective skull model 483 established from CT scans
